intro: Juncus conglomeratus typicus, commonly known as the clustered rush, is a perennial plant native to wetland habitats in North America. It forms dense clusters of narrow, grass-like leaves that are typically green to reddish in color. The plant produces small, inconspicuous brown flowers in late summer, which are arranged in spikes along the stem. It thrives in moist to wet soils and is often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. Due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for wildlife, it plays an important ecological role in wetland ecosystems.
